title: 114_hr2344
content: The "Veterans Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Improvement Act of 2015" approves courses of education and training for the Department of Veterans Affairs' Vocational Rehabilitation Program. The "Veterans Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Improvement Act of 2015" requires that courses pursued by veterans as part of a rehabilitation program must be approved for chapter 30 or 33 benefits. Waivers may be granted by the Secretary as deemed appropriate. This amendment applies to veterans starting a rehabilitation program under chapter 31, one year after the Act's enactment. Veterans enrolled in vocational rehabilitation programs may be eligible for specially adapted housing provided by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Section 2101(a)(2)(A) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include eligibility for a rehabilitation program under chapter 31 for veterans referred for assistance. Section 2102(d) is also amended to specify the amount of assistance available. The Secretary may waive limitations for veterans under section 2101(a)(2)(A)(iii) and submit biennial reports on the waiver authority. Dual eligibility for home adaptation services is barred for those receiving adaptive housing assistance. Effective date for amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary is authorized to prioritize vocational rehabilitation services based on need, considering factors like disability ratings, employment handicaps, income, and more. A plan describing any changes to service prioritization must be submitted to Congress 90 days in advance. SEC. 5. REDUCTION IN REDUNDANCY AND INEFFICIENCIES IN VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION CLAIMS PROCESSING. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs aims to streamline the processing of vocational rehabilitation claims by reducing redundancy and inefficiencies in information technology systems. This includes consolidating payment processing into one system and improving accuracy in accounting for services and outcomes for veterans in rehabilitation programs. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2016. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs aims to streamline vocational rehabilitation claims processing by improving information technology systems. $10,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2016. A report on changes made must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of enactment.
